subject: Re: [junit] Re: JUnit 4.x and support for Java 1.4

messageBody:
Hi Marvin,

Interesting points, thanks.

It's good to get the input from someone who's deep in the trenches and who
doesn't have the flexibility that a lot of us take for granted (such as
installing anything we want or even suggesting upgrades for no other reasons
than technical ones).

I'll address your last question:

On 9/15/06, Marvin Toll <MarvinToll@...> wrote:
>
> So - what I'm having trouble cost justifying is introducing a
> runtime influencing technology that simply is a stylistic
> programming change - from "test" to "@Test". There is no value-add
> here. Right? No additional value to customers and no additional
> value to developers. It is simply style.
>
> Or, am I fundamentally missing something.


Here is how I pitch annotations for testing.

First of all, putting "test" in front of a test method is really "adding
metadata to that method". You want to keep the method, but you are also
adding information for a specific, and telling this tool that this method
has a specific status. Now imagine that you want to do the same thing for,
say, a tool that will automatically generate RMI stubs, and suddenly your
methods need to be called "testRemoteFoo()". You can see where this leads.

The obvious place for this kind of information is in annotations.

This "older" way is also very intrusive: it forces you to certain namings
(methods start with "test"), certain structural constraints ("have to extend
a given base class", which is a big deal in Java since we only have one shot
at that) and also imposes you to a certain package hierarchy to keep track
of what tests are and where (package test.db, test.gui, etc...).

Once you embrace annotations and, in the case of TestNG, test groups, you
regain complete freedom to write your Java code the way you want. In
effect, your test classes look a lot more like simple Java code (if you
remove the annotations).

Additionally, test groups (@Test(groups = {"db", "fast"}) cleanly separate
your test structure from your Java structure. You are free to put your
classes in whatever package you like, and you will specify their test
category in these groups (additionally, test methods can belong to more than
one group, something you can't do if you're using package to organize your
tests).

--
Cédric
